natural solution: \end{eqnarray}The last series telescopes to $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10}$; thus, our our desired answer is $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10} = \boxed{\frac{11}{10}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> s n = (n powr 4 + 3 * n powr 2 + 10 * n + 10) / (2 powr n * (n powr 4 + 4))"
and h1 : "summable s"
shows  "suminf s = 11 / 10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the value of the infinite series \[
\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)}
\] The final Answer is \frac{11}{10}
 ### Proof
 We factor the denominator: \[n^4+4 = (n^2+2)^2-(2n)^2 = (n^2-2n+2)(n^2+2n+2).\]Now, \begin{eqnarray} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{n^4+4} & = & 1 + \frac{3n^2+10n+6}{n^4+4} \\ & = & 1 + \frac{4}{n^2-2n+2} - \frac{1}{n^2+2n+2} \\
 \Longrightarrow \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)} & = & \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^n} + \frac{4}{2^n\cdot(n^2-2n+2)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot(n^2+2n+2)} \\ & = & \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n-2}\cdot\left((n-1)^2+1\right)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot\left((n+1)^2+1\right)}
 \end{eqnarray}The last series telescopes to $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10}$; thus, our our desired answer is $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10} = \boxed{\frac{11}{10}}$.
 *)

fixes s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> s n = (n powr 4 + 3 * n powr 2 + 10 * n + 10) / (2 powr n * (n powr 4 + 4))"
and h1 : "summable s"
shows  "suminf s = 11 / 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> s n = (n powr 4 + 3 * n powr 2 + 10 * n + 10) / (2 powr n * (n powr 4 + 4))"
and h1 : "convergent s"
shows  "suminf s = 11/10"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the value of the infinite series \[
\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)}
\] The final Answer is \frac{11}{10}
 ### Proof
 We factor the denominator: \[n^4+4 = (n^2+2)^2-(2n)^2 = (n^2-2n+2)(n^2+2n+2).\]Now, \begin{eqnarray} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{n^4+4} & = & 1 + \frac{3n^2+10n+6}{n^4+4} \\ & = & 1 + \frac{4}{n^2-2n+2} - \frac{1}{n^2+2n+2} \\
 \Longrightarrow \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)} & = & \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^n} + \frac{4}{2^n\cdot(n^2-2n+2)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot(n^2+2n+2)} \\ & = & \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n-2}\cdot\left((n-1)^2+1\right)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot\left((n+1)^2+1\right)}
 \end{eqnarray}The last series telescopes to $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10}$; thus, our our desired answer is $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10} = \boxed{\frac{11}{10}}$.
 *)

fixes s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> s n = (n powr 4 + 3 * n powr 2 + 10 * n + 10) / (2 powr n * (n powr 4 + 4))"

theorem 
fixes n :: real and s :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

and h1 : "convergent (\<lambda>n. s n)"
shows  "suminf (\<lambda>n. s n) = 11 / 10"

(* ### Problem
 Compute the value of the infinite series \[
\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)}
\] The final Answer is \frac{11}{10}
 ### Proof
 We factor the denominator: \[n^4+4 = (n^2+2)^2-(2n)^2 = (n^2-2n+2)(n^2+2n+2).\]Now, \begin{eqnarray} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{n^4+4} & = & 1 + \frac{3n^2+10n+6}{n^4+4} \\ & = & 1 + \frac{4}{n^2-2n+2} - \frac{1}{n^2+2n+2} \\
 \Longrightarrow \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)} & = & \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^n} + \frac{4}{2^n\cdot(n^2-2n+2)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot(n^2+2n+2)} \\ & = & \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n-2}\cdot\left((n-1)^2+1\right)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot\left((n+1)^2+1\right)}
 \end{eqnarray}The last series telescopes to $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10}$; thus, our our desired answer is $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10} = \boxed{\frac{11}{10}}$.
 *)

 \Longrightarrow \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)} & = & \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^n} + \frac{4}{2^n\cdot(n^2-2n+2)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot(n^2+2n+2)} \\ & = & \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n-2}\cdot\left((n-1)^2+1\right)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot\left((n+1)^2+1\right)}

theorem 
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> f n = (n ^ 4 + 3 * n ^ 2 + 10 * n + 10) / (2 ^ n * (n ^ 4 + 4))"

shows  "suminf f = 11 / 10"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute the value of the infinite series \[
\sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)}
\] The final Answer is \frac{11}{10}
 ### Proof
 We factor the denominator: \[n^4+4 = (n^2+2)^2-(2n)^2 = (n^2-2n+2)(n^2+2n+2).\]Now, \begin{eqnarray} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{n^4+4} & = & 1 + \frac{3n^2+10n+6}{n^4+4} \\ & = & 1 + \frac{4}{n^2-2n+2} - \frac{1}{n^2+2n+2} \\
 \Longrightarrow \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{n^4+3n^2+10n+10}{2^n \cdot \left(n^4+4\right)} & = & \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^n} + \frac{4}{2^n\cdot(n^2-2n+2)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot(n^2+2n+2)} \\ & = & \frac{1}{2} + \sum_{n=2}^{\infty} \frac{1}{2^{n-2}\cdot\left((n-1)^2+1\right)} - \frac{1}{2^n\cdot\left((n+1)^2+1\right)}
 \end{eqnarray}The last series telescopes to $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10}$; thus, our our desired answer is $\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{10} = \boxed{\frac{11}{10}}$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 2 \<longrightarrow> f n = (n ^ 4 + 3 * n ^ 2 + 10 * n + 10) / (2 ^ n * (n ^ 4 + 4))"
and h1 : "convergent (\<lambda>n. \<Sum>i<n. f i)"
shows  "suminf f = 11 / 10"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

(* ### Problem

 *)
